newsitem.title: UK: London gold rolls higher, silver along for ride.
newsitem.headline: London gold rolls higher, silver along for ride.

text.p: Gold prices marched higher on Tuesday, building on gains posted the previous day, while the other metals followed its lead, dealers said. Amid bullish market sentiment, bullion fixed at $383.35 an ounce, the highest fixing in five weeks. It had fixed at $382.40 in the morning and $381.00 on Monday afternoon.
Dealers attributed gold's gains to market players covering short positions after prices tenaciously held above the key $380 level during downside tests over the past two weeks.

"What we're beginning to see is the traditional end-of-month shortcovering before the expiration of options," a dealer said. Options give the right but not the obligation to buy or sell metal at a given price.
But market opinion was mixed as to whether the rally indicated a recovery from its downtrend or a temporary blip higher before resuming its slide.
Gold drifted to 18-month lows earlier this month, undermined by indifference from investors and speculators and weaker than expected demand from the jewellery industry.

"I'm not convinced. I think we're just in a new $381-$383 range. The producer selling that was around last week to depress prices is still around," the dealer said. Strong resistance was expected at around $384 an ounce.
Still, a series of uptrending technical indicators on historical price charts suggested a forthcoming upswing, some technical analysts said.
"The sudden bursts of strength enjoyed by gold, platinum and silver yesterday much reduces downside risk," analyst Elli Gifford of Investment Research of Cambridge said in a report.
"Indeed there is a possibility the lows have been seen and a bout of worthwhile corrective strength could soon come through."

Gold prices have broken above a medium-term downtrend line which joins the peak of the February 1996 rally with highs in late August. A close above the trendline, currently at $381.60 an ounce, would confirm that breach, analysts said.
Silver followed gold higher and was trading at $4.96/$4.98 an ounce, up three cents from Monday's London close.
"It seemed to have tagged along for the ride," a dealer said. The psychological $5.00 was silver's key hurdle.
Platinum was trading $2.00 stronger compared to Monday's finish at $385.50/$386.50 an ounce. Palladium was $1.75 firmer at $118.25/$119.25. --Lida Poletz, London newsroom +44 171 542 2936
